title: scotlands-lockdown-phase-3-seven-key-dates-know-measures-eased
story: NICOLA Sturgeon yesterday set out key indicitive dates for further changes to lockdown rules in Scotland.Giving her three-weekly update to the Scottish Parliament, the First Minister confirmed that we would not be moving into Phase  of the route-map out of lockdown.The priority remains keeping the coronavirus prevalence low to get pupils back to school safely in August, with minimal changes to anything  in the coming weeks.She said that the Scottish Government estimates about  people in Scotland currently have Covid-. Last week that estimation was about .The R number is also still below one, she said.During the briefing she did, however, outline a series of indicitive dartes for further changes to rules - provided there is no sustained rise in the virus.Here we outline those seven dates:From August :The Scottish Government will pause the advice for peoples shielding in Scotland.From Saturday, they will follow the same guidance as the general population.But the First Minister has encouraged them to be especially carefully during their day-to-day lives.Today First Minister @NicolaSturgeonconfirmed that Scotlands schools will re-open full-time from  August, with enhanced public health measures in place and additional funding provided to support a safe .Read more ## https:t.co fzSBtcmTlJpic FfHKCgKbmdash Scottish GovernmentJuly , From August :Routine eyecare services can be carried out and counselling services like drug and alcohol support groups can provide essential services as long as physical distancing is observed.From August :Primary and secondary schools across Scotland should begin to reopen.No pupils will be required to physically distance or wear face masks, but pupils in secondary schools are to be encouraged to stay distant where possible.From August :Wider range of dental care can resume,including aerosol procedures for urgent cases.From August :By this date, all schools in Scotland should have reopened on a full-time basis.From August :It is hoped that physically distanced outdoor events like concerns can take place outdoor contact sports would be able to resume for all ages, bingo halls could reopen with physical distancing, funfairs could reopen and driving lessons can restart.The Scottish Government does not anticipate other changes coming before September , but Sturgeon said this would be kept under review.Gyms are set to reopen from September From September :It is hoped that sports stadia will be able to reopen with physical distancing in place, indoor sports courts could reopen for some activities, indoor soft play facilities could reopen.On the matter of gyms and swimming pools Sturgeon said she understands the desire for them to reopen, but that the clinical advice is they pose a ldquoparticular risk and require a particularly cautious approach.However the current indicative date is they could reopen from September .This will be reviewed in three weeks and could be brought forward.It is also hoped that entertainment sites and cultural venues like theatres can reopen from September  with physical distancing measures in place.

title: five-borders-communities-set-ultra-fast-broadband
story: FIVE communities in the Borders are to get new ultra-fast broadband.Galashiels, Tweedbank, Selkirk, Peebles and Hawick are among  places to benefit from the new poundbillion plan by Telecoms company Openreach.Borders MP John Lamont welcomed the news.He said: ldquoPoor broadband and mobile signal is one of the most common causes of complaints in the Borders."This has only intensied due to more and more people working from home over the last few months."Thatrsquos why I am delighted that Openreach is investing in better broadband across towns in Selkirkshire and Roxburghshire."Better broadband really makes a dference to peoplersquos lives for work and for recreation."Work is expected to get under way in many of the announced locations within the next - months.But due to the size of the build, some places will see work continue into .Clive Selley, chief executive of Openreach, said: ldquoThis year wersquove all seen the importance of having a decent broadband connection, and at Openreach wersquore convinced that full fibre technology can underpin the UKrsquos economic recovery."Wersquore determined to find inventive engineering solutions and effective partnership funding models to reduce costs and enable us to connect as many communities as possible across the UK without public subsidy."Openreach is leading the charge to help government achieve its target of making gigabit capable networks available nationwide by .ldquoWe hope that by publishing our own plans, we can help ensure that taxpayers only fund connections in communities that really need public support.

title: 15-things-weekend-scotland-lockdown-eases
story: Scotland is slowlybeginning to open back up.And as were all getting used to like taking on its new normal, we pulled together a list ofthings to do this weekend to get you out of the house.Here are the top  things to do this weekend:VISIT A CASTLE ndash CAERLAVEROCK CASTLEWhile the actual castle is currently closed, the grounds and green spaces of Caerlaverock Castle are now open for free as one of Scottish Tourismrsquosopen-air sites. The castlersquos wide moat, towered gatehouse and battlements make it look like something straight out of a fairytale.Caerlaverock CastleIn fact, the castle has been a popular filming location, featuring in films such as the Decoy Bride starring David Tenant. Gaze up at the formidable red sandstone defensive walls, unique in Britain for the triangular shape, and take in a piece of Scottish history.Caerlaverock Castle, Glencaple, Dumfries, DG RU.  .THE REAL MARY KINGrsquoS CLOSEThe Royal Mary Kingrsquos Close in Edinburgh opened back up to the public last Saturday. Located underneaththe Royal Mile, this five-star attraction features uniquely preserved th-century streets and has spent lockdown redesigning its tours to ensure the safety of staff and visitors alike ndash including preparing some exciting new tour features.The tours will run at % capacity and staff will be wearing masks and gloves where possible, maintaining a social distance at all times. The attraction has been given ldquoGood to Go status by VisitScotland, so visitors can be sure their safety is a priority. Delve into Edinburghrsquos murky history and explore places once inhabited by some of the cityrsquos most influential people.The Real Mary King Close, Warristonrsquos Close,  High Street, Edinburgh, EH PG. Tours run from am-.pm. Tickets from pound, can be booked onlineSLOANSPut down the takeaway menus and get yourself out for a good, old-fashioned sit-down, pub meal. Since  Sloans has been serving thirsty Glaswegians and this week they finally reopened their doors to the public.With a fully heated and covered outdoor courtyard, book yourself a spot outside. Or,itrsquos a little chilly and you want to stay inside, it has plenty of indoor seating on offer.Like everywhere, Sloans has made some important changes to ensure the safety of customers and employees alike, including social distancing, online bookings and contactless payments only, as well as regular cleaning and hand-sanitiser stations throughout the pub.Sloans,  Argyll Arcade,  Argyll Street, Glasgow, G BG. Monday-Sunday, noon-pm.   .THE SAINT BEER GARDENOne of the lesser known spots in St Andrews, The Saintrsquos beer garden is the perfect place to relax with a pint in the fresh air. After reopening its doors earlier this month, the Saint has put several measures in place to ensure the safety of staff and customers.These include temperature checks on arrival, as well as submitting your details for contact tracing. Booking in advance is mandatory and tables are limited to six people. But donrsquot worry ndash yoursquoll still have ample time to enjoy your drinks as you have your reservation for just less than two hours. Therersquos plenty of space to enjoy a relaxing drink not too far away from the hustle and bustle of the town centre.The Saint Bar  Kitchen,  South Street, St Andrews, KY EG.Monday-Sunday -pm.  .THE SCOTTISH GALLERYHead to the Scottish Gallery this weekend for your artistic fix! The gallery reopenedearlier this month and visitors can call or email the gallery to plan their visit ahead of time.Therersquos a host of exhibitions on show this month including Davy Brown at  ndash Brownrsquos th birthday exhibition with the galleryndash showcasing his still le and landscape painting.As well as The Edinburgh School exhibition, featuring pieces from artists associated with the Edinburgh College of Art after the First World War.The Scottish Gallery,  Dundas Street, Edinburgh, EH HZ. Tuesday-Friday am-pm and Saturday am-pm .HIGHLAND FOLK MUSEUMIf yoursquore looking for something educational to do in the north of Scotland in the coming weeks then the Highland Folk Museum is the place to go. Theyrsquore reopening on Wednesday and will be open every Wednesday through to Sunday, with visitors needing to pre-book their visit online.The collections on display at the museum mainly reflect the social and rural way of le in the Scottish Highlands from the s all the way through to the mid-s. Some of the collections include the Agricultural Collectionand the Domestic Collection with items ranging from cooking material through heating, lighting and laundry to traditional house fittings and furniture, along with many other collections, giving you ample opportunity to learn about all aspects of the history of the Scottish Highlands.Highland Folk Museum, Kingussie Road, Newtonmore, PH AY. Wednesday-Sunday .am-pm .  .TAKE A SCENIC DRIVE ndash ABERFOYLE TO CALLANDERFor a fun activity that doesnrsquot even involve getting out of the car, this scenic drive from Aberfoyle to Callander, via the Three Lochs Forest, is a perfect weekend activity.On this quiet forest road you can venture through the woodlands of the Queen Elizabeth Forest Park, which stretches almost eight miles, taking you past three enchanting lochs ndash Lochan Reoidhte, Loch Drunkie and Loch Achray.The drive only takes about an hour and  minutes but there are several car parks on the drive, as well as picnic areas and some short trailsyou fancy a walk to stretch your legs.,params: .pushAccess the entrance to the Three Lochs Forest Drive from the A just north of Aberfoyle . Departure point: Aberfoyle.CHECK OUT A FARMERSrsquo MARKET ndash LEITH MARKETAlthough farmersrsquo markets ed this month, they look very dferent, but are still a great day out. All traders will be at least two metres away from one another and there will be no hot food .Therersquos also no craft stalls at the moment, but therersquos plenty of fresh food for visitors to browse and purchase. Social distancing measures are being enforced and all staff are wearing masks.Leith Market Dock Place, EH LU.Open every Saturday from am-pm.HAVE A PICNIC AT ROWARDENNANThis tranquil spot on the banks of Loch Lomond is the perfect place for a summerrsquos day picnic. Take in the views of the loch and even go for a paddle at Rowardennan before you eat.Afterwards, the Ben Lomond Memorial Trail is a short, easy walk that ends at the Ben Lomond Memorial Park, which features the award-winning sculpture from artist Doug Cocker framing the peak of Ben Lomond.G AR is the nearest postcode ndash follow the signs from Drymen.CAMP AT HORGABOST CAMPSITENestled away at the south of Harris is the remote Horgabost Campsite, perfect for a weekend staycation.The views here stretch out over the water, interrupted only by the gentle rise of Taransay Island. title: pandemic-toughest-challenging-period-councils-history
story: THE coronavirus pandemic has been "without doubt the toughest and most challenging" period Scottish Borders Council has ever had to face, according to its leader.At a virtual meeting of the council on Thursday, elected members voted to take back emergency powers from the chief executive, Tracey Logan and hand them to Tweeddale East councillor Shona Haslam.Speaking at the meeting, councillor Haslam said: ldquoThe last five months have been, without doubt, the toughest and most challenging that this council has ever had to face.ldquoThe pressures on our staff and resources have been immense, the impact will be felt for years and will not be fully known for some time.ldquoThroughout this pandemic the officers of this council have had to take very swt decisions and react quickly to government guidance and I want to thank them for the efforts that they have made to fully consult with councillors all the way along.ldquoI also want to thank councillor Stuart Bell who has worked collegiately with myself throughout this situation to ensure that all councillors have felt fully engaged in any decisions that have been made.ldquoI want to thank the officers, staff and partners of the council for their incredible work over the last five months to respond to this ever changing situation that we have found ourselves in.ldquoBut I also want to particularly mention all of the incredible community volunteers, resilient community groups and COVID- response groups who have done so much in our community.ldquoThe level of community engagement and co-working with council services has been amazing to see and this is something that we must hold onto, and learn from for the future.Fellow Tweeddale East councillor Stuart Bell, who leads the main SNP opposition at the council, said: ldquoAs I said in March when these emergency powers were agreed, lsquoboldmeasures are needed to stop this pandemic overwhelming our way of lersquo.ldquoBold measures were taken, and now, the degree of normality that allows full-education to restart in our schools is the right point to resume normalcouncil business, and switch off the emergency provisions.ldquoBut I remind colleagues that two of the three concerns I expressed in Marchare still relevant.ldquoWhilst there is now a mechanism to continue making planning decisions,there remains a backlog of deferred decisions, and the financial consequencesof the lockdown are signicant and growing ndash whilst the same problem isfacing other local authorities, that doesnrsquot make it easier to address.ldquoI tried to give a message of hope in March and whilst there is more to hopefor there is now no less uncertainty.ldquoIt is estimated that only five per cent of the Scottish population has actually had COVID- which means that the best that almost all of us can hope, is that we maypersonally not be susceptible to a devastating infection that is all around us.ldquoThat is why in thanking the council staff for their application and flexibility, andalso thanking the general public for their forbearance, I particularly want tothank the hundreds of ordinary, neighbourly folk who have been supportinglocal community resilience.

title: young-borders-entrepreneurs-taking-business-hands
story: YOUNG entrepreneurs from across the Borders are emerging after lockdown.With studies predicting a steep rise in youth unemployment this year, some young people are taking matters into their own hands.Trystan Andrews, Arran Paterson and Callum Hastings recently launched a clothing business for outdoor wear.Describing bothybothy, the group said: ldquoWe always view bothy trips as a method of escape and re-setting our minds.ldquoWe were thankful for this discovery and thought it would be cruel not to share our passion for this magnicent aspect of le.ldquoOur comfortable clothes will remind you that there is always an option to escape the pressure of the modern world.ldquoThe name bothybothy was chosen as it is how we live our le. Simply waiting for the opportunity for another bothy trip.Currently, the company sells three T-shirt designs and one jumper design, with the potential for a wider range in the future.Bothybothy came to le after Callum combined his savings with those of Trystan and Arran, both . Callum recently turned .When this newspaper asked the group to identy the best thing about running their own business, they replied that they work how and when they choose.ldquoWe donrsquot need to report to anyone above us because we are all equals in this venture and make every decision as a group.They added: ldquoOur advice is to spend time researching all aspects thoroughly before ing straight in.Another fashion-minded Borderer is Ellen McFadzen, a -year-old from Selkirk.She had tohome from France when COVID- put a stop to her travel plans in March.However, she has used her spare time to pursue her love of fashion ndash and she now owns her own business.LoveNelle offers a made-to-measure range as well as bespoke garments. Ellen makes her own patterns, orders the fabrics, and markets the products.ldquoIrsquom quite a hands-on person who wants to do everything myself, said Ellen. ldquoBut my advice to young entrepreneurs is: lsquoDonrsquot be afraid to ask for helprsquo.ldquoI went into this not knowing how I could turn what I loved doing into a business, but here I am.Ellen was taught to sew by her granny and her hobby progressed during lockdown as she documented her style online for her friends and family.They encouraged her to pursue her sewing dream and turn her needle skills into a business.Ellen said: ldquoI love clothes that are more flamboyant than those you would traditionally find in stores.ldquoI want to break through fast fashion and throw-away culture by helping people embrace their quirks and not strive to follow each trend.ldquoI also want to make clothes that fit people without the stress of meeting standard shop sizes.

title: borders-cyclists-raise-5-000-katie-mckerracher-trust
story: THE magnicent edice of Bamburgh Castle provided a fitting backdrop to the completion of a -mile charity cycle undertaken at the weekend by two Borders couples.Selkirkrsquos Kenny and Shirley Houston, along with friends Andrew and Ann McKerracher of Ettrickbridge, had originally planned to take part in Aprilrsquos Etape Loch Ness cycling event, but its cancellation meant a complete rethink.Having already raised over pound, in sponsorship for the cancelled cycle, on Saturday the friends completed a similarly distanced route from the McKerrachersrsquo home in Ettrickbridge to the Northumberland village of Bamburgh .As well as finishing the -mile route in record time , what made the cyclistsrsquo achievement even more remarkable was the fact their sponsorship total has now rocketed to pound,.The money will go to the Katie McKerracher Trust, a charity established in  in memory of the McKerrachersrsquo -year-old daughter Katie, who died on January  that year from Dfuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma , a brain tumour on her brain stem.Since its formation in , the trust has assisted DIPG patients and their families in numerous ways ndash sending out copies of the trustrsquos DIPG information booklet, assisting with practical day-to-day issues, and working with health professionals to seek to improve the treatment of DIPG patients.Kenny, a retired police officer, chose the Bamburgh route as his mother Rhona hailed from the nearby village of Belford.At the end of the ride he said he had been ldquoabsolutely humbled by the number of people who had taken the time to support and sponsor the quartetrsquos efforts.ldquoThe sponsorship total has now increased to pound,, while the original aim had been to raise less than half of that.ldquoItrsquos a brilliant total to go to the Katie McKerracher Trust, which is a cause very dear to our hearts.Kennyrsquos we Shirley, a support officer at Hawick Police Station, said the cycle ride had been hard work but great fun.ldquoThe last eight miles was very hilly, but up until that point I couldnrsquot believe how quickly wersquod been going.ldquoThe favourable weather conditions helped, so all-in-all things couldnrsquot have gone any better.Friends, family and well-wishers gathered at Bamburgh to cheer the four cyclists across the finishing line, and the champagne flowed as everyone toasted the ridersrsquo superb efforts.ldquoEverything went pretty much according to plan, said Andrew McKerracher, whose parents Donald and Moira travelled down from their home in Perth to set up feed stations for the cyclists at Kelso and Ford.ldquoThere was plenty of good banter among the four of us ndash especially during the hilly climbs, added Andrew, who is vice-president procurement  supply chain with Galashiels-based pharmaceutical firm Kyowa Kirin International plc.,params: .pushldquoWe are very grateful to everyone who supported us on the day, and also to the many kind iniduals whorsquove made such generous donations.ldquoThe money raised will be invaluable in helping to further the trustrsquos work.To date, cycling events have played a major role in the Katie McKerracher Trustrsquos fundraising efforts.Ann McKerracher said the first major task was the Hebridean Cycle Challenge in .But reflecting on the most recent ride, Mrs McKerracher hailed an ldquoenjoyable cycle.The foster parent and Borders College achievement coach added: ldquoThe cycle to Bamburgh was a great experience, made all the more enjoyable by the support of family and friends along the way.ldquoThe most satisfying thing, however, is the fact so much money has been raised for the trust thanks to the generosity and kindness of supporters.Kenny Houstonrsquos fundraising exploits are well-known throughout the Borders and beyond. Diagnosed with bowel cancer in , and having undergone five major surgeries over the past five years, in  he organised a dinner and auction in support of the BGHrsquos Borders Cancer Centre and the Katie McKerracher Trust, with each organisation receiving a sum in excess of pound,.Last April he staged a dinner-dance and auction in Selkirkrsquos Haining House, raising a further pound, for the Borders Cancer Centre.He said: ldquoIrsquom delighted the four of us are raising funds for the Katie McKerracher Trust.ldquoShirley and I were extremely fond of Katie, and the trust has done an amazing job of supporting DIPG patients and their families over the past  years.Anyone still wishing to make a donation can do so through this website.

title: borders-workers-face-redundancy-johnstons-elgin
story: JOBS are at risk at Johnstons of Elgin in the Borders.The cashmere specialist has warned that  staff roles are under threat at its Hawick mill and Innerleithen premises.Further jobs are expected to go at the firms head office in Elgin, which also has a satellite site in Walkerburn.Simon Cotton, CEO of Johnstons of Elgin, said: ldquoWhile Johnstons of Elgin has strong long-term prospects, to meet the signicant short and medium-term impact of the COVID- pandemic we are restructuring the business."This reflects the new realities we are facing with stores in most of our markets around the world having been closed for several months and now faced with reducing high stock levels."Our community in Hawick is at the heart of our business as well as the incredible skills and capabilities of our team, therefore this is not a decision we have taken lightly, but out of necessity to protect the long-term health of the business."We will do everything within our power to mitigate the number of redundancies but we know that this will be an unsettling time for our workforce and our intention is to manage this process quickly and fairly."Our priority will be to maintain our exceptional skills and capabilities so that we can build on these in the future as the situation starts to improve again."

title: meghan-celebrate-39th-birthday
story: The Duchess of Sussex is celebrating her th birthday after a whirlwind  months that has seen her le transformed.A year ago Meghan was a working member of the British royal family and living in title: woman-claims-seen-prince-andrew-nightclub-virginia-giuffre
story: A lawyer for trafficking victims of disgraced American financier Jeffrey Epstein said she has given the FBI information from a woman claiming she saw the Duke of York with alleged victim Virginia Giuffre at a London nightclub.Prince Andrew has previously denied Ms Giuffrersquos claim he was at the Mayfair establishment with her on the night in question ndash March   ndash saying he was at home after visiting a Pizza Express in Woking with his daughter Beatrice.However, US lawyer Lisa Bloom said another woman has come forward to support Ms Giuffrersquos version of events.Ms Bloom said Shukri Walker recalls seeing Andrew at the club with Ms Giuffre ndash then known as Virginia Roberts ndash and Epsteinrsquos girlfriend Ghislaine Maxwell.Maxwell is now in jail in the US on charges of trafficking minors for her former partner and the British socialite, who has pleaded not guilty, will go on trial in July .Ms Bloom said she has forwarded Ms Walkerrsquos information to the FBI.Prosecutors working on the Epstein trafficking case have accused Andrew of refusing to cooperate with requests to interview him about his contacts with Epstein, who killed himself in a New York prison last year while awaiting trial on child sex trafficking charges.Andrew has said in recent weeks that he is cooperating with the FBI investigation into Epstein.Ms Bloom told the PA news agency in an email: ldquoI can confirm that I spoke to the FBI and gave them all of the information Shukri provided to me.ldquoShe credibly alleges that she was there at the Tramp nightclub in  and specically recalls Prince Andrew being there with Virginia Roberts Giuffre and Ghislaine Maxwell.ldquoShe had never been in the presence of a royal before or since and so it was very memorable to her.ldquoShe was disappointed when she saw Prince Andrewrsquos now infamous interview where he denied being there.vw,vw,px, px"Virginia Giuffre says she had sex with Prince Andrew three times Ms Bloom added: ldquoI represent six victims of Jeffrey Epstein. We demand that everyone who helped him abuse girls be brought to justice.ldquoAnd we demand that everyone with information about Epstein or Maxwell, including Prince Andrew, assist authorities by providing full information and documentation.Ms Giuffre claimed she had sex with Andrew on three separate occasions, and was aged  on the first occasion.She has claimed in a now-settled US defamation lawsuit ndash documents from which were released last week ndash and in other litigation, that Maxwell recruited her in  to be a sexual servant for Epstein.The duke categorically denies he had any form of sexual contact or relationship with Ms Giuffre.vw,vw,px, px"Ghislaine Maxwell and the Duke of York, seen leaving a society wedding in  Ms Walker told The Sun newspaper she recalls Andrew having been at Tramp because she accidentally stepped on his foot while dancing.She told the paper she had decided to speak out after watching Andrewrsquos denials in his now infamous BBC Newsnight interview about his friendship with Epstein and Ms Giuffrersquos allegations.ldquoWhen I watched the BBC interview and saw Prince Andrew deny knowing Virginia, saying he has no recollection of that night I had to come forward, Ms Walker was quoted as saying.ldquoBecause I was there and I do have a recollection of it.The Sun reported the FBI had decided it did not need Ms Walkerrsquos testimony despite being given her evidence by Ms Bloom.An FBI spokeswoman told the PA news agency it would not comment on the developments surrounding Ms Walker..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Woman claims to have seen Prince Andrew at nightclub with Virginia Giuffre

title: asian-markets-follow-wall-street-green
story: The Asian markets have continued their rally following Wall Streetrsquos advance, suggesting investors are shrugging of coronavirus fears.Shares advanced across Asia on Tuesday after Wall Street closed broadly higher on encouraging economic reports, starting off August by closing within % of the record high it set in February.Tokyorsquos Nikkei  gained .% to ,. and the Hang Seng in Hong Kong added .% to ,..The SP  added another .% onto its four-month winning streak, closing within % of the record high it set in February at ,..Big Tech led the way higher again, and Microsoft and Apple alone accounted for most of the SP rsquos gain.The rally followed reports showing that manufacturing has improved across much of the world, including in China, Europe and the United States.With the total coronavirus caseload rising by less than , for two straight days, investors bet that US outbreaks might be moderating, said Jeffrey Halley of Oanda.ldquoHopes rose that the US might avoid a deeper recession, which was all financial markets needed to send equity markets higher, and for the US dollar to continue recovering some of its recent losses, Mr Halley said.Microsoft jumped .% on Monday after it confirmed that it is in talks to buy the US arm of TikTok, a Chinese-owned video app that is very popular but has also drawn the White Housersquos scrutiny.Microsoft said its chief executive officer Satya Nadella has discussed the issue with President Donald Trump, and the tech giant expects the talks with TikTok to end no later than September , either with a deal or without.Apple added .%, piling more gains onto its .% rise on Friday following a report showing that its profits during the spring easily topped Wall Streetrsquos expectations..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Asian markets follow Wall Street into the green

title: east-lothians-football-teams-back-september
story: The countyrsquos six senior football teams have been left on the sidelines since March, when the coronavirus pandemic brought the season to a premature close.Now, early discussions have identied a possible start for the new campaign.The Lowland East South West Pyramid group ndash representing teams from the Scottish Lowland Football League, the East of Scotland Football League, the South of Scotland Football League and the West of Scotland Football League ndash held its first Zoom call earlier this month.Clubs are hoping to restart training in the coming weeks, with a view to playing again at the end of September or beginning of October.Managers from East Lothianrsquos teams cautiously welcomed the announcement and hoped it was the start of light at the end of the tunnel.Geoff Jones, manager of Dunbar United, said: ldquoI think, to be honest, it is an enormous boost.ldquoNot just from a football perspective but just a mental health perspective as well ndash for a lot of people to get back to doing some level of group interaction.ldquoWe have pushed ndash as have a lot of clubs ndash inidual training programmes through virtual apps, like Strava, but some people are highly motivated and others find it dficult outwith a group environment.Meanwhile, Johnny Harvey was looking forward to starting his first full season in charge of Tranent Juniors, having been appointed in February.The Foresters Park side will be looking to build on a promising campaign, which saw them sitting fourth in the East of Scotland Football League Premier Division when the season was stopped.Harvey said: ldquoTo get some kind of normality back in everybodyrsquos lives would be a huge boost.ldquoSupporters, players, myself ndash everybody is exactly the same and is excited to get back on the field as soon as possible.Kevin McDonald, manager at Musselburgh Athletic, was frustrated to see football halted in the spring with his side on an impressive run of form, including securing a place in this seasonrsquos Scottish Cup after a - thumping of Mid Annandale in the South and East Shield.Now, he is hoping to see that continue when the upcoming campaign gets under way.He said: ldquoI have been pestering the secretary at Musselburgh to find outhe has any information.ldquoWe are all desperate to get back ndash myself and the players are the same.ldquoWe will be looking at a seven-month break by the time we restart games.ldquoThe sooner we are allowed to get back training and playing friendlies the better.ldquoI think we will need more friendlies with not playing for so long as well.Joe Hamill, player-manager at Haddington Athletic, said everyone at the club was keen to see the season get back under way.He stressed that training could look slightly dferent than it did previously, with stringent cleaning measures being put in place to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.He said: ldquoItrsquos a wee bit of light at the end of the tunnel for us. Irsquove been getting messages from the players asking lsquowhen are we starting back rsquoldquoIrsquom in the same boat and just want to get on with it.

title: special-tv-appearance-family-tiktok-marathon
story: Eight-year-old Mary Kidd, mum Karen, dad Gordon and older sister Abbie, , appeared on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best on Sunday, July , the pairrsquos chat show style programme.They appeared on the show, presented by father-and-son duo Martin and Roman Kemp, thanks to Maryrsquos six-hour TikTok dance marathon, which she completed on VE Day in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.Karen, a board member at the foundation, said: ldquoI got a message on Facebook from a producer at Cactus TV [an independent TV production company which owns runs the show], they were looking for inspirational families for the show.ldquoI was a wee bit unsure at first but the girl we spoke to was nice.ldquoThey saw Maryrsquos story online, I think it was the Courier online, and askedthey could give us a phone call.ldquoSo we had a couple of phone calls with them and they found out what happened and about the charity etc, like a pre-interview.ldquoRoman is also a big TikTok fan so he was really interested.The show was filmed on June  and took about one hour and  minutes in total to record. It was broadcast on STV ITV at .am last Sunday morning, July .As well as chats with actor and Spandau Ballet member Martin Kemp and his radio DJ and Irsquom a Celebrity... Get Me Out Of Here! star son Roman, the family played some games and spoke to the showrsquos three guests Laura Whitmore, Beverly Knight and Jessie Ware.Karen said: ldquoWe just had normal chats with them, they made us feel very, very welcome. The whole experience was really good. They had some great chats with Mary.ldquoMartin and Roman were so nice and made us feel very at ease.ldquoI was more of a Duran Duran fan but I didnrsquot tell him that!ldquoItrsquos nice that they are recognising kids that have done something that wee bit dferent.ldquoIt was also nice to see what it takes to film a TV show and how it is all done ndash Roman fluffed his lines a couple of times. It was an honour and a privilege to have had the opportunity from ITV.Ahead of watching the show, Karen admitted she was nervous.However, afterwards she described it as ldquoone of the most surreal experiences and said she was really pleased with how the show turned out.She said that both Mary and Abbie also loved filming the show.She added a thanks to Mary for doing her TikTok challenge, which raised more than pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.

title: pictures-prestonpans-lockdown-gala-day
story: Like many events in the county, the annual Prestonpans Childrenrsquos Gala was impacted by the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.The galarsquos organising committee had several discussions and, following advice from both East Lothian Council and the Scottish Government, it first postponed and then cancelled the gala day, which had been due to be held on June .However, the committee still wanted to recognise and mark the day.One suggestion was to give all of those in the royal court a goodie bag and rename the event, so instead it held what it called lsquoLockdown Gala Dayrsquo.Graeme Hutchison, gala convenor, told the Courier: ldquoThis was to encourage the kids and remind them that we hadnrsquot forgotten that this should have been their special day.ldquoThis idea kind of grew thanks to our chairperson Vikki Burns suggesting we could have an alternative gala day parade.The parade consisted of the gala committee members decorating their cars with balloons and bows in gala colours.They then travelled around Prestonpans, stopping at the houses of each member of the royal court to deliver them their goodie bag, honking their horns as they passed.Graeme said: ldquoIn the lead-up to gala day there was still a buzz about the town people were still showing their support by putting up their bunting and the parents of the royal court were being made aware we would be visiting. Nobody knew what to expect.ldquoGala day itself was amazing, from the glorious weather to the great response we got from the locals as we travelled around in convoy tooting and waving, visiting many streets of the town which the normal gala parade doesnrsquot visit. The people of Prestonpans certainly came out to show their support and for that we are truly grateful.ldquoWe would like to take this opportunity to thank the future Queen Lily [Bennion] and her royal court, as well as their families for their patience and understanding. Thanks to Connor from Sneddon Media for travelling with us and capturing the fantastic photos, which are on our Facebook page lsquoPrestonpans Gala Dayrsquo.ldquoFinally, thanks to the dedicated committee members who once again gave up their time to make the event possible.ldquoWe hope to be back doing some fundraisers in the not too distant future to help us fund and prepare as we look forward to Gala Day  on Saturday, June .After Lockdown Gala Day, Graeme took to social media to share his thoughts on the event.He said: ldquoPrestonpans, you didnrsquot disappoint us.ldquoThe fantastic efforts made from everyone to put up your bunting and decorate your streets, please repeat this next year. It was great to see so many of you as we travelled around as many streets as we could while visiting the members of the royal court.ldquoTo the royal court children, we didnrsquot want to forget that it would have been your day, we can still have your special day next year.ldquoTo Queen Lily, you were absolutely stunning, even reducing some of the committee to tears your mum and dad will be proud of you, the way you conducted yourself on what should have been your special day. To you, the community of Prestonpans for coming out and showing your appreciation as we passed by quietlyin our cars, doing the alternative gala parade. Hopefully you enjoyed it.He also thanked his fellow gala committee members for giving up their time and ensuring gala day traditions continued.

title: pop-up-cycle-lane-coastal-road
story: While mph speed limits are being introduced in Prestonpans and Cockenzie and Port Seton.As part of the Spaces for People initiative to provide additional space for physical distancing to protect public health, work has started on a temporary cycle route between Prestonpans and Cockenzie and Port Seton which will run parallel to the main B Edinburgh Road.The three-metre wide path will be created by laying hard surfacing down on the grass verge on the north side of the carriageway between the two communities.The path will run alongside the footpath between the boatyard access at Prestonpans to just past the old power station with a white line separating the cyclepath and walkway.This is the councilrsquos latest project to improvesocial distancing in the wake of the Covid- crisis.The local authority received pound.million from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Spaces for People fund to introduce ious countywide measures to make it easier to social distance in town centres and improve cycle and pedestrian paths.As well as the roadside cycle route, the speed limit on Edinburgh Road, which is normally mph, will be reduced to mph and speed limits in the twocommunities reduced to just mph.The plan for the cycle path has seen dozens of painted stones created by local schoolchildren, which line the footpath, move across to the other side of the road.The stones are a symbol of hope and unity during the Covid- crisis, and many similar displays have been created throughout East Lothian and the whole country.Councillor Norman Hampshire, environment spokesperson at East Lothian Council, said: ldquoWe received many comments in the public consultation around Spaces for People on the need to provide suitable space for people cycling.ldquoMany people are currently cycling this route and we need to cater for the current increase in cyclists during the pandemic period.ldquoIn common with other Spaces for People measures, this route is for temporary use as we gradually move out of restrictions and will also provide a viable alternative to the use of the private car and or public transport for shorter-distanced essential or leisure trips in the area.The works also include the introduction of temporary crossings of Edinburgh Road at either end of the route through the use of lsquobuildoutsrsquo and bolt-down bollards.In addition, the proposals also include traffic calming measures on Edinburgh Road to slow down traffic with a temporary reduction in the speed limit to mph between the two communities, in tandem with the introduction of mph limits within the communities themselves.MrHampshire added: ldquoWe were aware of a collection of painted stones that have been carefully laid by local schoolchildren alongside the existing footway along Edinburgh Road and recognise that these are important to the local community.ldquoThe community council arranged for these to be carefully collected prior to the start of the works and they have been relocated on the other side of the road.

title: pans-snake-slithers-across-road-new-home
story: The Pans Snake has stretched from the eastern edge of Prestonpans towards neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton since it was born at the beginning of April.However, with plans for a temporary cycle path to be created beside busy Edinburgh Road, the snake had to find a new home... on the other side of the road.Emma Orphant was among those spending  minutes on Sunday evening moving the snake from the north side of the road.She said: ldquoWe lost count of the number of stones at ,!ldquoWe moved them across the road because the council are putting in a temporary cycle path.ldquoOn Sunday, volunteers and children moved them across the road.ldquoIt has just been a nice thing for people when they are out for a walk to look for.ldquoIt is for the kids.Youngsters and adults started working on the Pans Snake at the beginning of April, with lockdown restrictions in effect.Similar schemes have taken place where across the country, including the Windygoul Worm in Tranent.The snake started at the bus stop beside the Greenhills at Prestonpans, with Emma, who is depute manager at Seahorse Nursery in Cockenzie, keen to see it stretch the near half-mile to the neighbouring village.Emma, who lives in Prestonpans, was pleased to say that the snake had been a success and admitted she had a few favourite stones.She picked out those from youngsters saying they were missing school or with messages including their name and teacherrsquos name from school as her favourites.Beyond the coronavirus, Emma ndash and a number of people on social media ndash was keen to see the snake find a permanent home, with the possibility of the stones being cemented into the wall beside the footpath.

title: beach-boardwalk-look-blooming-great-thanks-volunteers
story: The team has been working hard over the last fortnight to create plant beds along one side of the walkway as it carries out landscaping work on the site.The boardwalk was created two years ago across the road from the holiday village to provide easy access to the beach for wheelchair users and, thanks to grants from the Walk With Scott Foundation and Beach Wheelchairs charity, two beach wheelchairs are available to borrow from Seton Sands.Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom said that the boardwalk, which also has three picnic tables and seats, had become a popular place for locals and holidaymakers all year round and members were delighted to be able to start work on its surroundings.A spokesperson said: ldquoIt was always our intention to landscape the area around the boardwalk and we are delighted that this work has finally got under way.ldquoOver the last two weeks, members of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom, assisted by several enthusiastic and hard-working volunteers, have transformed one side of the boardwalk.ldquoA long raised bed has been sited alongside the pavement.ldquoA rockery has been created at the beginning of the boardwalk.ldquoSoil was provided by East Lothian Council and the areas planted up with plants suitable for the exposed situation near the sea, which will, in time, provide colour and interest for most of the summer.ldquoIn due course, we hope to make similar improvements to the other side of the boardwalk.

title: luxury-hampers-given-students-covid-19-efforts
story: A total of pound, has been allocated by Santander Universities to provide gts to , students at QMU and Edinburgh Napier University who supported the NHS in the fight against the virus.QMU has offered its nursing and allied health professionsrsquo students on the frontline a choice of one of two luxury food hampers ndash a lsquopamper hamperrsquo or breakfast hamper.The gts have been provided by Artisan Larder Scotland, founded by QMU graduate David McVey.Edinburgh Napier University has linked up with East Lothian-based sushi company Minato Sushi to offer its own eligible School of Health and Social Care students a pound voucher for the business as a thank you for their efforts as part of the countryrsquos Covid- response.Sir Paul Grice, principal and vice-chancellor of Queen Margaret University, said: ldquoWe are incredibly proud of all of our students from the School of Health Sciences, especially those who are playing their part in the NHSrsquos fight against Covid-.ldquoThanks to the continuing generosity and support of Santander Universities, we have been able to not only provide this thank you gt for hundreds of our hard-working health students but also support one of our graduate businesses in the process."I hope the students enjoy the gt ndash they are doing fantastic work.

title: 50-000-secures-future-youth-organisation-recharge
story: Recharge, which works with young people aged from  to  in the Farsquoside area, was given the five-figure sum by The Robertson Trust.The pound, goes towards the managerrsquos position, starting next January.Alan Bell, manager at Recharge, was delighted with the funding announcement.He said: ldquoIt is massive, especially this year. This was the last year of our current funding and we did not have any beyond that.ldquoTo receive three years of funding has confirmed the future of the organisation.Mr Bell, who has been involved with the group for more than a decade, said the organisation provided support for young people.The coronavirus pandemic had changed how the organisation worked, with services instead moving online.However, as restrictions ease, Mr Bell was confident those services would start to go back to the way they were.It is also hoped they could be back in their Tranent base this autumn.Councillor Colin McGinn, who represents the Tranent, Wallyford and Macmerry ward, is a trustee of Recharge.He too was delighted with the funding announcement and highlighted the importance of Mr Bell.He said: ldquoIrsquom absolutely delighted because it is a crucial bit of funding for us.ldquoAlan Bell is so key to that and Recharge running well. His influence is fantastic and it really, really helps us planning for the next year.Recharge works with young people to help increase their confidence, esteem and skills.Support is also given to young people and families with issues that are affecting them.Instead of face-to-face meetings, Recharge has been mainly working remotely and supporting young people through video links and phone calls, as well as pulling together a webpage of resources that can be accessed at home.The Robertson Trustrsquos mission is to improve the quality of le and realise the potential of Scotlandrsquos people and communities, with a particular focus on health, social and educational inequalities across Scotland.

title: tesco-seeks-drop-cash-obligation
story: The company says it no longer owns land ndash the site of its former store at Mall Avenue ndash which is to be turned into  flats by a developer.Tesco has applied to East Lothian Council to mody a contract which was part of an earlier planning consent for residential development at the town centre site, dating back to .The sum of pound, had to be given for extra accommodation at Musselburgh Burgh Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School.Pritchett Planning Consultancy, on behalf of Tesco Stores Limited, said Tesco now owned and operated the supermarket and petrol filling station at Olivebank Road.It stated: ldquoTesco was previously involved in a land transaction which enabled residential development to be constructed on the site of the former Tesco store site. This transaction took place over a decade ago and the land of the residential development site is not owned by Tesco.ldquoThe section  agreement states that Tesco Stores Limited shall pay an education contribution relating to a residential development on land identied as the third subjects.ldquoTesco has no ownership of the subject site and is not involved in any way in developing the land for residential purposes.The document added: ldquoThis proposed modication to the section  agreement by Tesco seeks to remove Tescorsquos name from the agreement and to replace this with the lsquothird proprietorsrsquo as owners of the residential land on the third subject site.ldquoIn making this change, the agreement would be more aligned with government policy on legal obligations as the agreement would bind the landowner to which the agreement relates rather than a third party which has no involvement in the land or its development.

title: new-art-exhibition-highlights-beauty-dunbar
story: Edinburgh-based Ann Cowan spent time in the town throughout  and earlier this year.Her work ndash Dunbar Sketchbooks ndash will feature in Gullanersquos Fidra Fine Art, alongside Dominique Cameronrsquos Moor, which focuses on Rannoch Moor, west of Pitlochry.Although not the intention of either artist, both bodies of work are devoid of human figures.Ann, the daughter of an architect and an artist, found that her eye was naturally drawn to the architecture and streets in and around Dunbar.She said: ldquoThe town has a wealth of beautul old red sandstone buildings with interesting architectural details.ldquoOrange pan tiles form wonderful roofscapes.ldquoThe industrial outskirts are grittier, but just as interesting in terms of composition.ldquoThe harbour is a constant source of inspiration with its fishing boats and lobster creels.ldquoFollow the clfs of deep burnt sienna along the coast, past Winterfield to Belhaven and you discover miles of sandy beach with tall ochre grasses set against colourful beach chalets.Ann gave up a career in law to become a full-time artist.She grew up in the Borders, with Dunbar a town she has known for many years.Alan Rae, who owns the gallery, was a fan of both artists and was looking forward to the exhibition, which gets under way on August .He said: ldquoAnnrsquos loose and expressive drawing, sometimes supported by textural patches of collage, combines with an organic palette enlivened with flashes blue, yellow and the rich red of the local East Lothian sandstone.ldquoPainted in a spontaneous sketchbook style, the result is a broad and tender portrait of a much-loved town.The gallery owner said that the coronavirus lockdown had proven dficult for the arts sector.Fidra Fine Arts reopened its doors at the end of last month with the Mixed Summer Exhibition.Mr Rae added: ldquoWhen the lockdown began, it was a really anxious time.ldquoGallery owners always want to do the best for their artists and I wasnrsquot sure how it would play out with this exhibition.ldquoHappily, we will be welcoming visitors to view this wonderful work in August.

title: teenager-interviews-legends-scottish-football
story: Angus Blacklock has spent lockdown tracking down some of Scottish footballrsquos best-known faces and speaking to them for his new YouTube channel.The youngster is keen to get into sports journalism when he leaves North Berwick High School and has made a start by interviewing famous names.He said: ldquoFrom an early age, I knew I was never going to be a footballer.ldquoI always wanted to have a career in sport and football really.ldquoI like listening to podcasts and wanted to get into the media. Hopefully, this puts me in good stead and is a good thing to have on your CV.The -year-old had been thinking about launching the online channel but found himself without the time to do it due to schoolwork.It was during an online course with Youth Football Scotlandthat the idea started to take shape.He said: ldquoMy first interview was with John Collins, who lives nearby.ldquoI was nervous and did already know him and had spoken to him but not in depth about his career.ldquoIt was good to speak to him about that.Since speaking to the former Hibs, Celtic and Monaco midfielder, who famously scored for Scotland against Brazil in the World Cup in , Angus has continued to interview big names.Often a chat with one former player led to a chat with another ndash assuming they were happy to pass on contact details for the next interviewee!Angus said: ldquoProbably the most high profile would be John Hartson [former Arsenal, Celtic and Wales striker]. Irsquove spoken to Ryan McGowan [who scored for Hearts against Hibs in the  Scottish Cup], former Courier reporter Joel Sked, Kevin Murphy [manager of Hearts Women] and Gary Locke [Scottish Cup winner with Hearts].Angus also interviewed John Hughes, who led Inverness Caledonian Thistle to the Scottish Cup in .Now, the teenage season ticket holder at Tynecastle has targeted securing an interview with Heartsrsquo new first-team head coach Robbie Neilson and ing number one Craig Gordon.The Aberlady resident told the Courier he had loved football since he was five years old.His dad, Robin, is no stranger to the beautul game either.In , Robin took on the EuroChampsChallenge, where he set off on a ,-mile car trek that took him to the home stadium of every football team to have ever won the European Cup Champions League.At that time,  clubs in  cities across  countries had lted the top prize in European football, with Angus visiting Celtic Park, Anfield and Old Trafford before his dad travelled overseas.The memorable trip saw Robin and friends raise pound, for charities Changing Faces and the Sick Kids Friendsrsquo Foundation, now the Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity.To view Angusrsquo videos, go to YouTube and search for Angus Blacklock.

title: covid-19-testing-centre-returns-former-power-station-site
story: It re-started todayand runs until Wednesday at the site on Edinburgh Road, am-pm.Tests can be booked through the UK Governmentrsquos online system, www.gov.uk get-coronavirus-test, for those who are key workers or those who live with one.Alternatively they can be booked through the NHS website at www.nhs.uk conditions coronavirus-covid-A limited number of home testing kits are available for those who cannot make it to the testing site, but priority will continue to be given to key workers and can be secured by booking through their employer.As of May , testing is for people who have symptoms and are over the age of five as well as household members who are experiencing symptoms.Symptoms include a new continuous cough, a fever and a loss or change in smell or taste.Anyone who develops symptoms is asked to self-isolate immediately as well as all members of their household until they receive a negative test result.More information on testing is available at www.gov.scot publications coronavirus-covid--getting-testedThis is not the first time Covid- testing has taken place at the former power station site.A mobile testing unit first visited the site between May  and  and later visited again from May -June .It was operated by the st Infantry Brigade which oversees the army reserve units in Scotland.

title: coronavirus-people-scotland-can-take-part-covid-19-vaccine-trial
story: Speaking at the Scottish Governments daily briefing yesterday,Deputy chief medical officer Nicola Steedman asked members of the public to consider whether they could volunteer during the testing phase of the drug.Last week, findings from the early phases of a vaccine being created by Oxford University were published, with Ms Steedman saying the vaccine was both safe and created a ldquogood response in the more than  test subjects.She added: ldquoItrsquos still early days, but itrsquos definitely good news.Ms Steedman said: ldquoScience and research has never been more important than it is now.Larger-scale trials will be required to ensure that vaccines can be rigorously tested in the coming months and Ms Steedman has said a registry has been set up across the UK for people to sign up to be a part of Covid- trials.Ms Steedman said, adding: ldquoPlease do visit the online siteyou can and think about whether you, like so many others, can volunteer to help with vaccine trials.Online sign-up can be found at www.nhs.uk researchcontactIf you are interested in volunteering for #COVID vaccine studies, you can register and find out more at https:t.co ZYZzEbI https:t.co WhQfkZSsThe First Minister confirmedanother four positive cases of the virusin Scotland, bringing the total to ,.No deaths have been recorded in the last  hours, meaning the total number of fatalities remains at .But NicolaSturgeon said the Scottish Government is likely to adopt a ldquocautious approach to lockdown easing when its planned review takes place on Thursday.She warned there is a ldquoworrying resurgence of Covid cases globally and stressed the hospitality sector in Scotland must ensure it is adhering to guidelines put in place.

title: new-conservative-leader-east-lothian
story: Councillor Jane Henderson, leader of the opposition, has announced her plans to retire from her role as councillor at the next local authority election in two years time.And the group has named Councillor Lachlan Bruce, the youngest elected member of the council and a Courier columnist, as its new group leader.It is expected that the council will be asked to formally appoint Councillor Bruce as leader of the opposition when it meets next month.Councillor Henderson said: "Over the course of the lockdown, I decided for personal reasons that I would not be standing in  and believe this is the right moment for the Conservative Group to elect a new leader who can spearhead our efforts as we move into the critical months ahead."It has been a real honour to lead the group over the last two years, where we have effectively held the minority Labour administration to account and pressed home the shortcomings in SNP Governmentfunding in East Lothian."I look forward to continuing to represent North Berwick Coastal ward over the period ahead and will give Lachlan and the Conservative Group my full support as we approach the crucial elections in and ."Councillor Bruce said: "I would like to thank Jane for her sterling efforts and dedication as Conservative Group leader. Jane has worked tirelessly with the group and council officers to ensure we have delivered effective opposition and I look forward to continuing to do this in the months ahead."The new Conservative Group leader said he would be working closely with colleagues to probe East Lothian Councils budget and finances following year-on-year reductions in core funding from theSNP Government and signicant financial problems resulting from shortfalls in income and additional expenditure due to Covid-.He said: "The councils financial position has deteriorated signicantly since the Covid- pandemic and we will be pressing both the Labour administration and the SNP Government for prudent spending and a fair funding deal to avoid signicant disruption to core services."Councillor Henderson took over the role of group leader after Councillor Brian Small resigned from his position as opposition leader in , one year after an election which saw seven Conservativecouncillors win seats and move into the opposition role against a minority Labour administration of nine councillors in charge, while the SNP had six councillors.Councillor Small, who almost died after being struck down by sepsis, later resigned as a councillor after accusing his group of being more interested in "opposing the SNP" than challenging the administration.Tim Jackson, chairman of East Lothian Conservatives, said: "Jane Henderson has been a very effective group leader and I would like to thank her for all she has done, particularly during the unprecedented events of recent months."As she hands over the role to Lachlan Bruce, I am sure we will continue to see our Conservative councillors providing constructive opposition in the council chamber."

title: cafe-near-north-berwick-goes-revamp-ahead-reopening
story: DRIFT is found in Canty Bay, east of North Berwick and its owners are urging people to support agritourism businesses.It delayed its planned July  reopening, but its owners Joanna McNicol and her husband Stuart continued to work hard to get the cafe ready ahead of its reopening on Monday .The cafe is also locatednear the couples family farm about half a mile away.As well as an inside space, which will not be opened straight away, DRIFT has an upgraded outdoor seating area with bespoke palette tables, making the most of its coastal surroundings.It is this outdoor space which is currently open, a takeaway service is also available.Also new is a horse trailer, which acts as a new serving area for outdoor customers.Joannasaid: ldquoThere is nowhere quite like DRIFT in relation to its offer, its location and its unique set up. It has been built out of love and something we are incredibly proud of.ldquoThe cafeacute has become an integral part of the community and a fantastic visitor destination for those touring the east coast so we are incredibly excited to be reopening and getting back to what we do best.ldquoWe have been inundated with people asking when we will be able to reopen and with lockdown limiting so many in towns and cities we expect to see a surge in visitors keen to enjoy open space and the great outdoors.DRIFT is perfectly placed to serve just that.ldquoWe are very lucky to enjoy some of the best views on offer and the wildle and sea le around here is remarkable. Just last week we witnessed a pod of dolphins playing not too far from the shore ndash itrsquos something we will never take for granted and are eager to share with our customers.ldquoIn the last few months agritourism has taken a real blow and the pandemic has been brutally dficult for many small businesses. I am hopeful that as lockdown eases the nation will support small entrepreneurial businesses and keep places like DRIFT alive.The cafe opened in line with Visit Scotlands newhealth and safety industry standard lsquoWersquore Good To Gorsquo which reassures customers that a Covid- risk assessment hasbeen completed and the business is adhering to all of the appropriategovernment and public health guidance.The scheme has set the standard across the whole of the UK in conjunction with over  industry bodies.DRIFT welcomes visitors from across the globe and makes its food using local or Scottish produce.Last year it welcomed more than , visitors to enjoy its food and homebaking, which uses local produce where possible.For more information visit DRIFTs Facebook page.

title: new-bus-service-set-introduced
story: August  will see the launch of the new  service, which links Humbie, East Saltoun, Pencaitland, New Winton, Elphinstone, Tranent and Macmerry to the East Lothian Community Hospital and Haddington High Street.There will be four journeys to the community hospital in Haddington and fivejourneys from Tranent and Elphinstone, with several journeys extended to Humbie, East Saltoun and Pencaitland.Elphinstone will have  daily journeys, with most of the existing  servicersquos daytime journeys replaced with those of the .This will provide residents of Elphinstone with the option to stop at Asda and Aldi in Tranent, as well as connecting them to the community hospital.Meanwhile, Prentice is stopping its offer of free travel to NHS workers, a service it has provided since April  as a thank you during the Covid- outbreak.As Scotland moves out of lockdown and into a lsquonew normalrsquo, Prentice has decided to end the offer tomorrow .

title: seabird-centre-delighted-open
story: The centre, an independent charity based in North Berwick, reopened last Thursday for the first time in four months after it closed its doors in March due to the coronavirus pandemic.Several new systems were put in place but people were said to have been accommodating and supportive.Due to its long period of closure and these new systems, the centre was open from Thursday until Sunday last week and then closed Monday to Wednesday.This allowed staff, all of whom had been on furlough, the time to adjust to the new ways of working and enhanced safety measures, as well as the chance to review the experience to seeany improvements were needed.The opening is said to have gone well and without any major issues.A spokesperson said: ldquoWersquove all needed to adapt very quickly but are happy to say that members and visitors have been hugely understanding and supportive of the changes.ldquoWe will open again daily from Thursday and canrsquot wait!The bookable timed visits to its newly refurbished Discovery Experience were fully booked all weekend, as were the wildle boat trips.The next step is to bring back the outdoor learning programme, with plans to celebrate National Marine Weekthrough bookable outdoor activities.

title: prevent-skin-irritation-wearing-face-mask
story: WHETHERyoure an essential worker or someone who has to run necessary errands,youre out in public during the coronaviruspandemic, youre likely wearing a face mask.And while face masks can help prevent the spread of the virus, they can also irritate your skinyoure wearing one for an extended period of time. lsquoHaving to wear a mask for  hours is hardrsquo, Kayla F., a nurse in Washington, D.C. says. lsquoIts uncomfortable on my ears and nose and it also chafes my face and has led to a lot of breakouts on my chin and lower cheeksrsquo.To help you stay safe while also keeping your face healthy, we asked a dermatologist along with our own beauty expert for their top tips on preventingskin irritation caused by face masks.How face masks can irritate your skinBreakouts can be one side effect of mask use. Credit: Jevelin Getty ImagesAnything that rubs against your face for hours on end is bound to cause some irritationmdashand face masks are no dferent. lsquoWhen it comes to cloth or surgical masks, we are primarily seeing mild skin irritation, mild comedones , and reactions to the fabric itselfrsquo, Allie McAllister, BSN, FNP-C, DCNP, explains. lsquoWhile just wearing a mask can cause friction which can be irritating to the skin, the types of materials, dyes, and detergents in the mask can also cause irritation and rashesrsquo.Besides rashes and chafing, face masks can also lead to breakouts. It makes sense when you think about itmdashyour mask is creating a moist, warm environment against your skin, which is perfect for bacteria to thrive. lsquoBreakouts can occur from sweat, dirt, and moisture being trapped under the maskrsquo, McAllister says.How to protect your skin from your face maskAlways start with a clean face. Credit: Getty ImagesFor starters, McAllister says you should always thoroughly wash your face before you put on your mask and after you take it off Cerave Hydrating Facial Cleanser in particular because its gentle and non-irritating. Then, McAllister recommends, lsquoIf you know yoursquoll be wearing your mask for a long period of time I would suggest applying a thin layer of Aquaphor Healing Ointment to the areas that will come in direct contact with the mask.rsquoYou can also try an anti-chafing balm, like Body Glide which is is a favourite of Reviewed staffers who run. Apply it on areas where your mask typically rubs against your skin, like the nose, cheeks, chin, or ears.Keep in mind, too you should wash your face mask regularly in the laundrymdashand McAllister agrees. She suggests using a detergent specically for sensitive skin thats free of any dyes or perfumes.Bonus: If you have the luxury of picking and choosing your mask , McAllister says the type of fabric can make a big dference in your masks comfort. She recommends a soft cotton fabric thats more breathable than other alternatives.McAllister says once again to start with Aquaphoryou notice any irritation or discomfort. However, she advises that you speak to a dermatologistthe irritation is more severe or does not resolve with Aquaphor.And as for breakouts, our lestyle writer and beauty guru Jessica Kasparian has a few products she swears by. lsquoIf a blemish pops up, I love the Mario Badescu Drying Lotion, which uses isopropyl alcohol to dry up pimples and calamine lotion to soothersquo, she says, adding, lsquoI also love hydrocolloid patches like the CosRX Acne Pimple Master Patch set. Theyre clear dots that extract impurities while also creating a protective layer over the pimple so nothing  can irritate itrsquo. Jessica also says that she makes sure to focus on her chin and lower face when washing her face since thats the area covered by a mask.The product experts at Reviewed have all your shopping needs covered. Follow Reviewed on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram for the latest deals, product reviews, and more.Prices were accurate at the time this article was published but may change over time.

title: highway-code-make-significant-changes-cyclists-pedestrians
story: Heres a round-up of what is changing.A new ldquohierarchy of road users which puts the greatest responsibility for reducing danger onto drivers is among proposals announced as part of a Department for Transport consultation on updating the road usersrsquo hand book.What other changes are set to be made The planned updates also include:Announcing the consultation, the DfT explained: "[The hierarchy of road users] ensures that those road users who can do the greatest harm have the greatest responsibility to reduce the danger or threat they may pose to other road users."The objective of the hierarchy is not to give priority to pedestrians, cyclists and horse riders in every situation, but rather to ensure a more mutually respectful and considerate culture of safe and effective road use that benefits all users.This principle, it added: ldquoapplies most strongly to drivers of large goods and passenger vehicles, followed by vans minibuses, cars taxis and motorcycles.The other major changes include rules to create clearer and stronger priorities for pedestrians, particularly at junctions, and clary where pedestrians have right of way.This will include recommending cars and bikes turning into or out of side roads give way to pedestrians waiting to cross.The third major point of the updates will place a requirement on drivers to give priority to cyclists when they are turning into or out of a junction, or changing direction or lane, just as they would to other motor vehicles.Specic guidance for drivers sets out the speeds and distances drivers should observe when passin cyclists and horse riders.The new text says drivers passing cyclists should leave a gap of at least . metres at speeds under mph and at least two metres at more than mph.It also says they should not pass horses at more than mph and with a gap of at least two metres.The updated Code will also recommend drivers adopt the ldquoDutch reach method of getting out of a car.This means using the hand furthest from the door to pull the handle, which forces you to twist your body, making it more likely yoursquoll see a cyclist approaching from behind.EV drivers will also be warned to ensure charging cables do not present a trip hazard for pedestrians and new guidance will highlight the growing use of blanket mph zones in place of the standard mph limit in urban areas.What has the reaction been to the planned changes The RAC said it broadly welcomed the proposed changes but said the right-of-way changes needed clarication for everybodys safety.RAC head of roads policy Nicholas Lyes said: "Overall the ambition behind the proposed Highway Code changes is to make the roads safer for everyone."A part of that is making it crystal clear we all have a shared responsibility to ensure one anotherrsquos safety on the road, whether you are travelling on foot, on a bicycle or in a motor vehicle."Many other changes made to the Code, such as recommending the lsquoDutch reachrsquo when exiting a vehicle to check for cyclists and taking care when charging electric vehicles, are also very sound.ldquoWe also welcome the new guidance contained in the Code on the safe passing of roadside workers."Every day, our patrols and recovery workers put themselves at risk to help others and the more that can be done to protect them, the safer that job becomes.ldquoItrsquos vital now that every final change made to the Code is well communicated."While drivers should keep up with changes to the Highway Code, our research suggests only half have consulted it at any time in the last  years.

title: campers-vandalism-beauty-spot-slammed
story: The shocking disclosure was made by East Lothian Council Countryside Rangers, who said that the woods at Tyninghame and the nearby beach had become an increasingly popular spot for campers.Illegal fires have been set, with hundreds of people in the area and no toilet facilities on the site.A post on social media by the Countryside Rangers, highlighting the issue, said: ldquoWe have been seeing an unprecedented number of people camping on our sites.ldquoOnly wild camping is permitted in the countryside ndash light-weight and done in small numbers. Large tents and large groups are not wild camping. On Saturday, July , Tyninghame alone had  tents.ldquoOf these,  were camping illegally. That equated to roughly  people camping and thatrsquos  people who will need to go to the toilet on a sitewith no facilities.Issues have moved from litter to irresponsible fires and human faeces being left behind.They noted  ldquoirresponsible fires at Tyninghame.They added: ldquoIt is illegal tohave a fire in a woodland and a ring of stones is not responsible, nor would it prevent a fire from spreading.ldquoStones have been known to heat up and explode! Having a fire in a woodland or grassland risks the fire spreading and also leaves a large scar.ldquoOf the estimated  campers, it was clear that most had not thought about how they would responsibly go to the toilet the World War One tank blocks have become toilet blocks toilet paper and human waste everywhere.ldquoOnly two groups were being completely responsible and were true wild campers.ldquoWe encourage everyone planning a trip to the countryside to consider the Scottish Outdoor Access Code ndash know how to access the countryside responsibly.Councillor Norman Hampshire, East Lothian Council spokesman for the environment, said that finding human faeces was ldquodisgusting for the Countryside Rangers.He said: ldquoWe have to accept that, because there are restrictions on where people can go on holiday, people are looking for locations where they can get away from large crowds.ldquoWhen we have got  people all doing the same thing it is not delivering that.ldquoWe have got issues at Tyninghame with the number of people who have discovered it is a fantastic location.ldquoPeople are coming from all over to use it.ldquoWe have no toilet facilities at this location and it is something the council needs to put in place as quickly as possible.ldquoI think wild camping is something lots of people do nowadays and we just have to manage it the best we can and try to educate people to stop them doing things they should not at these locations, and respect the environment that they are enjoying.Allison Cosgrove, vicechairwoman of Dunpender Community Council, described it as ldquohorrible.She said: ldquoWe are very happy that people want to come and see the area but we do want them to camp responsibly."I understand that there are toilets open at Whitesands and John Muir Country Park.Iain Gray, MSP for East Lothian, said: ldquoResponsible wild campers make sure they do no damage to the countryside they love, but this kind of illegal, irresponsible and potentially dangerous camping is simply vandalism and needs to stop.ldquoCommunities in East Lothian are welcoming of visitors and we need tourists more than ever at this time, but notthey are fouling and damaging our coastline and beauty spots in this way.ldquoGiven that lsquostaycationsrsquo are likely to be more popular for some time to come, it is vital that public authorities do more to discourage illegal camping and raise awareness about how to behave responsibly in the countryside.Kenny MacAskill, the countyrsquos MP, said: ldquoOur right to roam is embedded in the Scottish soul. Wild camping has been enjoyed for years and enjoyed by those wanting to get closer to our land.ldquoBut whilst access to the land runs deep it must not be abused.ldquoFarmers have rights most especially, but so does our natural environment, which is there to be cherished not trashed.ldquoThose enjoying the outdoors must respect the right to do that or face consequences.ldquoPublic agencies are under pressure but enforcement is necessary.ldquoWe all have a duty to call this behaviour out. That way, we can all continue to enjoy spending quality time in the nature thatrsquos on our doorstep.A council spokeswoman said there was currently no legislation in place to allow enforcement action.From Musselburgh along the county coast, there had been ldquounprecedented numbers of visitors in the past few weeks, said the spokeswoman.Some coastal car parks had to be closed at times because they were full, including at Tyninghame, which is located just south of Whitekirk and about two miles north-east of East Linton Gullane and Yellowcraig, by Dirleton.The Scottish Outdoor Access Code can be found at www.outdooraccess-scotland.scot

title: shop-owner-thankful-invaluable-support-pandemic
